review_title: Top Employer, Very Professional, Great Benefits.
pros: Fantastic employer that invests in their employees and actually cares about making an impact. Paid ongoing training, paid certifications, even opportunities to take some college courses. The company has high values, so overall I've worked with wonderful coworkers from all different backgrounds and locations. The company has remote positions due to COVID, but not sure how much longer they will keep those. They paid for the equipment to work from home. Paid internet stipend, free health insurance, and lots of other paid benefits across the company, great PTO. Everyone can interact with the directors, which says a lot about the company. Great networking opportunities and you may get to work with government or different organizations. Can't say enough positive things about this company. Several coworkers look forward to clocking in for work.
cons: Some positions are limited-term positions that largely depend how they're funded, but they offer better benefits than most permanent jobs. If you can't work weekends, some projects or positions may require weekends. I believe some positions have a fixed schedule, while others can change from time to time. It'll say in the job description.

pros: Good coworkers I really enjoyed working there

pros: Benefits are great. HR is largely supportive. Onboarding process is very well organized. Nice offices on the 10th floor. Flexible schedules are appreciated.
cons:
PHI really just functions as an umbrella institution with 70+ programs and initiatives that act like nonprofit organizations. Each program and initiative is responsible for fundraising for projects and admin costs and need to give a certain percentage of funds to PHI.

I joined a program that has underspent funds consistently for years which has led to a few big donors pulling out their investment or reducing their commitment from the program. 

I also saw shockingly bad management practices. For example, the program lied about the state of funding to staff, telling them that everyone's position is safe but not saying that it's only for another 6 months if no big funding comes in. The program laid off project coordinators with only two weeks' notice when they've known about it for 8 months. The program has allowed business travel combined with personal travel and charging personal expenses to the program.

review_title: Caring Employer, Needed More Oversight of Management
pros:
As an organization, I really felt PHI cared about it's employees personally and professionally. Pay was very good if you knew to negotiate, and raises came yearly. Benefits were excellent, though fairly expensive if relying on them for a family. As an employee, you pay into SDI, so I was able to take nice long maternity leaves. 

In my position, I was not micromanaged, yet at times there was a complete lack of guidance...especially when I first started. I had zero introduction to my job duties or expectations. Though I had to aggressively advocate for my promotions,  it was worth it to work with some very seasoned and talented staff who taught me a lot.
cons:
- Faily expensive benefits
- At times, too little guidance from supervisor
- Not enough oversight of senior management at our site; many complaints about Program Director after numerous staff were mistreated, yet seemed like HR was unaware

review_title: Tecnical Advisor - Global Health Fellows Program II
pros: Generous contribution to 403(b), support for professional development
cons: GHFP's salary negotiation process is ridiculous  and is neither transparent nor logical. It is unclear how they determine years of experience. They have no understanding of what fellows actually do on behalf of USAID and are not equipped to make a determination of salary. GHFP is naive to think that fellows do not talk to one another and understand the major disparities in salaries between people with similar experience performing similar work. I would never recommend GHFP to a friend after the experience negotiating my salary and feeling undervalued, misunderstood, and marginalized.  GHFP is only able to get away with this because people want to work at USAID.

pros: Great benefits, generous retirement contributions, excellent Paid Time Off accrual rates, worthy mission, and passionate coworkers.
cons: PHI programs are essentially autonomous and there is no real oversight of program leadership. Program leaders are technical experts but often lack the necessary training to effectively manage people. My former managers ignored PHI policies and procedures, were willfully ignorant of state labor law, and regularly invented new policies that only applied to particular members of staff, wth loop holes for management and specific "favorites."  In the case of my previous program, one particular manager regularly bullied, belittled, and intimided members of support staff on a daily basis and repeatedly made unprofessional comments that were ignored by the program's PI, as well as PHI central. The environment at my former program became so toxic that I had no choice but to look for a new opportunity.

review_title: Great organization dedicated to employee development
pros: PHI is a great place to work overall. Good work-life balance, enjoyable work environment, and colleagues that are supportive of your career and personal development. The organization offers great benefits and resources to their employees, with leadership that value their employees' well-being both at work and outside of work. Being surrounded by programs working in different areas of public health sets the stage for valuable learning opportunities, as well.
cons: The programs at PHI are siloed, which can make it difficult to feel connected to the greater organization. Your experience as an employee really depends on the program you work for, or if you work for the administrative arm of the organization (which supports all the different programs). The administrative arm of PHI does make efforts to engage all employees with trainings and town halls.

review_title: I loved this place until I complained.
pros: Great benefits. Pretty good pay. Nice location.
cons: Complaint process is lacking. Managers need more training in ethics and integrity.

review_title: PHI cares about their employees and is very passionate about their work.
pros: They offer a flexible work environment with a focus on good health at work.
cons: My program had a contract with the State of California, which wad kind of a nightmare. The State had several of the most incompetent employees you could imagine but were able to take credit for the great work PHI employees did. It was really an us vs. them type of environment.

review_title: organization with a mission and concern for employees
pros: There are many opportunities for working on new projects and career  growth.  The benefits are great and comp is competitive.  Most important is the mission and interest in public health.  I am able to balance being a parent with my work.
cons: The  need to fund-raise in a non-profit environment is getting harder so there is constant pressure.  There needs to be more support for programs to develop new business because there are a lot of ideas that need support.

pros: Accomplished colleagues, powerful programs, a diversity of issue and focus areas. Programs run independently with administrative support from central staff and office, no micromanagement or barriers to work from central office.
cons: Programs run themselves, meaning they are expected to bring in their own funding. Very little support for organizational development or fundraising. Since they run so independently, programs are often very siloed despite sharing PHI as their parent organization. Central office is very supportive within its capacity.

pros: Strong infrastructure in which to develop a project and feel secure in the organization that stands behind you. Wonderful benefits and competitive compensation.
cons: The same structure and hierarchy that protects programs and projects can also stifle a project's ability to respond quickly to the shifting global health landscape. Has some of the typical challenges of working within a bureaucracy, for better of for worse.

review_title: Great Benefits, Lack PD and Growth
pros: Benefits are amazing: health/gym, commuter, wageworks. More diverse than the average non-profit. Salary is pretty good but can be slightly more competitive. Great work/life balance.
cons: Systems and office space are antiquated and things are still done via filling out, printing & scanning forms rather than electronic. Office environment feels like you work in a maze rather than a collaborative space. Management lack the managerial skills to empower their staff to grow and explore options within the organization.

job_title: Research Associate III in Berkeley, CA
pros: Benefits are very good. Employer contributes a solid 10% to 403b no matter how much you put in. Very generous paid time off.
cons: Depends on the department you are work for. Work is super boring. No growth opportunities. You can sit there the whole day doing nothing. With that being said you have not much to learn. Paid is also low. Overall, this is kind of the laid back job for those who are close to retirement and looking for stability. If you are knowledgeable and enthusiastic go find more challenging and better paid job.

pros: Very good benefits and employee support (particularly for a USAID contractor). Great way to work for USAID.
cons: no transparency around salaries, what the different scales for different level Fellows. When asked about salaries, a range, increase one is met with hostility. This is an organization of mostly women and women run. Starting to feel like women keeping women down.

job_title: Research Scientist in San Francisco, CA
pros: it is a very collaborative, democratic environment to work in.  Each employee has the opportunity to do what is of most interest to him/her in his/her area of expertise.
cons: funding is a problem.  There is often an anxiety surrounding the ability or otherwise of getting a grant.

pros: PHI Programs do amazing work in the areas of cancer research, alcohol and tobacco as well as climate change. From my observation, PHI managers are supportive of their team members. There are many opportunities given the 200 plus programs at PHI. PHI HR Team is supportive as well. They have an excellent benefit program. The corporate culture is mission driven.Bonus, they have Peet's coffee.
cons: Perhaps an additional espresso machine? :)

review_title:
Clinical Research Interviewer/Coordinator
PHI ARG New Leaf Treatment Center
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Lafayette, CA
pros: gain experience in your field. good benefits, holidays, time off. there are lots of other jobs with PHI to look into.
cons: RUN! multiple people have left because of disorganization. it’s not worth your sanity.  it’s a close knit group that have know each other for decades, they do not offer opportunities for growth, and they seem content with the high turnover. look for other jobs at PHI, not this group.

pros: You will learn a lot about Oncology and gain experience for your resume. The PTO and health benefits are comparable to those of the private sector.
cons:
ons
This company has the worst work environment I’ve ever experienced. Management does not care about their employees wellbeing at all, and treats employees as easily replaceable, although they also can’t ever find enough employees to work here. You will be expected to keep up with an excessive workload because of the continual turnover, and management will not help or support you in any way. There is quite literally no room for advancement in this company. They would rather leave management positions empty for almost 2 years rather than internally hire any of their current employees. All managers are externally hired because there is no trust in or mentoring of the current employees. The work environment can only be described as constant chaos, because some employees are given a huge workload while other employees just sit around gossiping and bad mouthing others all day. Don’t expect your coworkers to support you either, in fact, expect them to throw you under the bus at any moment because of the every man for himself attitude that the company encourages. If you enjoy working in an extremely toxic environment, being treated like you don’t matter at all despite your frantic efforts to keep up with the unsustainable workload, and being degraded by your coworkers, HR, your supervisors, and upper management, then this is the place for you. If you expect a professional work environment free of childish coworkers gossiping and causing drama; to be trained and supported by any of your managers, or to leave work for the day feeling anything other exhausted, frustrated and beaten down, then definitely don’t work here. This company has been the worst place I’ve ever worked, which is sad considering that the point of the organization is to help children with cancer, but that goal is clearly second to stroking the manager’s egos. Working here will mostly just take a toll on your mental health and self-esteem until you find another job, like the majority of the hardworking employees here do. Don’t waste your time, health or humanity working for a company that makes it very clear that they couldn’t care less about you as a human being.

Advice to Management
Hire new management, especially the senior director, if you want the turnover to stop. Take your managers off of their pedestals and have them actually interact with the employees and expect them to treat employees respectfully. Don’t allow cliques to form or bullying to go on just because one employee has been working with the company longer than another. Management isn’t only about getting the job done. If employees are quitting nonstop, take that as a sign that something needs to change. Stop encouraging bullying and gossiping in the work environment by holding management and older employees accountable for their behavior rather than blame new employees for any problems that were going on long before they started. Start trusting your employees, appreciate them more, and acknowledge that some employees have a much larger workload. This is obvious to everyone, and denying this doesn’t change the fact that it is happening. Your open door policy should also include confidentiality, so that people will feel comfortable speaking on any topic without the fear of repercussion by management or their fellow coworkers because HR and management can not take confidentiality seriously. This company is carefully towing the line of illegality with the way it is run and needs to be completely revamped. Get rid of the older employees that believe they are above being reprimanded for their behavior and continue to cause problems throughout the company.

review_title: Committed people working for a good mission and values. Putting people first.
pros: Salary and benefits and opportunities to grow and try new work. Even when reductions happen staff are given advance knowledge and support
cons: Nonprofits are always getting squeezed financially so little extra funding for staff training and investing in some needed jobs.  Need more fundraising to grow

pros: Not much about pros since cons takes all the points.

pros: Very good benefits and competitive salary. Work can be very interesting depending on your focus area/PI.
cons: CEO is losing large contracts. There seems to be growing pains with too much oversight surround PI's. CEO is forcing non-PhD. candidates out of important roles.

pros: Supportive environment for small and large public health programs.  They provide the infrastructure to let innovative programs focus on what they do best. They also ensure that employees are well taken care of with an excellent benefit package that helps programs attract and retain great staff.

review_title: Research Opportunities in an Era of Health Reform
job_title: Research Program Director in Oakland, CA
pros:
Entry-level through advanced opportunities to get involved in advancing public health policy and practice.
Friendly work environment, considerable flexibility in work schedule, and comprehensive benefits.
Strong organizational leadership and vision for advancing public health policy and practice.
cons:
Research positions are not on an employee basis but contingent on the availability of program funding.
Challenging funding environment as largely dependent on government and foundation funds.

pros: PHI offers a great benefits package and is doing interesting work on a wide variety of health topics.
cons: There seems to be little career/ salary development. People stay in the same role until they leave the organization

pros: Outstanding learning experience. Interns worked with USAID staff; everyone was dedicated and driven. Many opportunities to attend various meetings, brown-bags and network. Great opportunity for interns to learn about USAID and the projects they are working on.
cons: Not really a con, but experience widely varies depending on team and supervisor you work with.

review_title: Great Mission but Ineffective Oversight of Programs
pros: Good benefits, competitive pay for a nonprofit, development opportunities
cons: When programs are far from HQ, there can often be little to no oversight, and poor program leadership goes unnoticed and unchallenged. The inability to hold staff and leaders accountable led to low morale across the program and loss of good talent.

review_title: Work among a talented, friendly bunch of researchers.
pros: PHI is leading the field in important ways, and offers a variety of avenues to engage in issues that matter.
cons: With so many research arms, coordination among researchers can be difficult. PHI attempts to bring together a variety of efforts, and often does well, but the bureaucratic overhead can be taxing for some.

review_title: PHI is often disorganized and mismanages Fellows - but overall experience team dependent
pros:
-It's a way to gain experience with a major public health institute.
-Allow travel/living internationally
cons:
-PHI does not care very much about fellows as individuals, they care more about keeping their government contract.
-They often distribute contradictory information about the fellowship.
-They are not overly communicative.

review_title: This organization is top-notch, in terms of nonprofits. In the projects, the employee experience is quite variable.
pros:
- Many opportunities for professional development, such as in-person courses, online learning management
- In my role, opportunities to travel domestically and meet with high-level organizational officials
cons:
- Limited growth opportunities (smaller organization)
- Limited understanding of "PHI Central" operations

review_title: Great place to work with excellent salaries and really good benefits
pros:
The salaries and benefits for a non-profit organization are better than the rest of the market; healthcare benefits are top of the line
Room for advancement or movement within programs
cons: If you're working for one of the programs, not much interaction with the umbrella organization

pros: People are very respectful, positive and knowledgeable. Access to advanced technologies was easily procured and links to major universities makes this organization an excellent choice of employer.

pros: PHI is a great non-profit! Great projects, awesome people who care for the well-being of several different communities. Great benefits, too!
cons: There are so many different projects that you don't really get to know anyone outside your own.

pros: PHI is full of sincere commitment and integrity.
cons: Funding in the public health arena can be tenuous, which causes transitions that can impede the strength and longevity of promising programs.

review_title: Best place to learn, grow and be well compensated
pros: Career opportunities that allow for growth and job satisfaction.  Senior management is understanding, approachable and encouraging of professional and personal growth.
cons: Benefits (particularly dental)  could be better but for a non-profit the pay is far better than most.

pros: great benefits if interning 6 months or longer. including professional guidance support throughout the internship, healthcare coverage, networking opportunities, and professional development events.

pros: This was a great way to jump start my career.

pros: Very nice company to work at and wonderful people. I love the programs that the company offers to the community.

review_title: A mission driven organization that gets talented people to work toward health equity and healthy communities.
pros: good work environment and benefits, great colleagues, makes a difference in people's lives.
cons: always have to fundraise to keep programs going

review_title: Worse place I've ever worked for
job_title: Desktop Support Technician in Oakland, CA
pros: It was good in the beginning before the management changes.
cons: Upper management.  Manage through fear.  Horrible, conniving, underhanded group I have ever met in my life.  Deceitful without morals or standards.   Underpaid, overworked.  Backstabbing and lies.

pros: Small software team. Friendly co-workers. Keeping up with latest technologies. Good location. Close to BART.
cons: The department I was in was not located very near the main Public Health Institutes headquarters.

pros: Experience working with funding agencies, liaising with country teams and working with multisectoral agents (WHO, CDC, etc.)
cons: fast paced, stressful, office politics, you can become jaded

pros: My project team was small and everyone had strong work ethic. Manager was available at all times.
cons: Not too much mixing with other project teams.
